sp.p: Yes, Sir; I knows the Groom, and one of the Houſe-maids: for the matter-o'-that, ſhe's my own Couſin; and it was my Mother that holp'd her to the place.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Do you know Lady Frances's Maid?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: I can't ſay as how I know ſhe.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Do you know Sir George's Valet?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: No, Sir; but Sally is very thick with Mr. Gibſon, Sir George's Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then go there directly, and employ Sally to diſcover whether her Maſter goes to Lady Brilliant's this evening; and, if he does, the name of the ſhop that ſold his Habit.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Be exact in your intelligence, and come to me at Boodle's. Exit Dick. If I cannot otherwiſe ſucceed, I'll beguile her as Jove did Alcmena, in the ſhape of her Huſband. The poſſeſſion of ſo fine a Woman — the triumph over Saville, are each a ſufficient motive; and united, they ſhall be reſiſtleſs.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: The air has recover'd me! What have I been doing! Perhaps my petulance may be the cauſe of her ruin, whoſe honour I aſſerted:—his vanity is piqued;— and where Women are concerned, Courtall can be a villain.
sp.stage: Enter Dick, Bows, and paſſes haſtily.
sp.p: Ha! that's his Servant!—Dick!

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: returning Sir.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Where are you going, Dick?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Going! I am going, Sir, where my Maſter ſent me.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Well anſwer'd;—but I have a particular reaſon for my enquiry, and you muſt tell me.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, I am going to call upon a Couſin of mine, that lives at Sir George Touchwood's.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Very well.—There, gives him money you muſt make your Couſin drink my health.—What are you going about?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I believe 'tis no harm, or elſeways I am ſure I would not blab.—I am only going to ax if Sir George goes to the Maſquerade to-night, and what Dreſs he wears.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Enough! Now, Dick, if you will call at my lodgings in your way back, and acquaint me with your Couſin's intelligence, I'll double the trifle I have given you.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Bleſs your honour, I'll call—never fear.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Surely the occaſion may juſtify the means:—'tis doubly my duty to be Lady Frances's Protector. Courtall, I ſee, is planning an artful ſcheme; but Saville ſhall out-plot him. Exit Saville.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Sir George Touchwood's.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: For ſhame, Sir George! you have left Lady Frances in tears.—How can you afflict her?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: 'Tis I that am afflicted;—my dream of happineſs is over.—Lady Frances and I are diſunited.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: The Devil! Why, you have been in town but ten days: ſhe can have made no acquaintance for a Commons affair yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Pho! 'tis our minds that are diſunited: ſhe no longer places her whole delight in me; ſhe has yielded herſelf up to the world!

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Yielded herſelf up to the World! Why did you not bring her to town in a Cage? Then ſhe might have taken a peep at the World!—But, after all, what has the World done? A twelvemonth ſince you was the gayeſt fellow in it:—If any body aſk'd who dreſſes beſt?—Sir George Touchwood.—Who is the moſt gallant Man? Sir George Touchwood.—Who is the moſt wedded to Amuſement and Diſſipation? Sir George Touchwood.— And now Sir George is metamorphoſed into a ſour Cenſor; and talks of Faſhionable Life with as much bitterneſs, as the old crabbed Fellow in Rome.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: The moment I became poſſeſſed of ſuch a jewel as Lady Frances, every thing wore a different complexion: that Society in which I liv'd with ſo much éclat, became the object of my terror; and I think of the manners of Polite Life, as I do of the atmoſphere of a Peſt-houſe.—My Wife is already infected; ſhe was ſet upon this morning by Maids, Widows, and Bachelors, who carried her off in triumph, in ſpite of my diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Aye, to be ſure; there would have been no triumph in the caſe, if you had not oppos'd it:—but I have heard the whole ſtory from Mrs. Rackett; and I aſſure you, Lady Frances didn't enjoy the morning at all;—ſhe wiſh'd for you fifty times.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Indeed! Are you ſure of that?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Perfectly ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I wiſh I had known it:—my uneaſineſs at dinner was occaſioned by very different ideas.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Here then ſhe comes, to receive your apology; but if ſhe is true Woman, her diſpleaſure will riſe in proportion to your contrition; — and till you grow careleſs about her pardon, ſhe won't grant it: — however, I'll leave you.—Matrimonial Duets are ſeldom ſet in the ſtyle I like. Exit Villers.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p:
The ſweet ſorrow that glitters in theſe eyes, I
cannot bear embracing her. Look chearfully, you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: I cannot look otherwiſe, if you are pleas'd with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Well, Fanny, to-day you made your entrée in the Faſhionable World; tell me honeſtly the impreſſions you receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir George, I was ſo hurried from place to place, that I had not time to find out what my impreſſions were.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: That's the very ſpirit of the life you have choſen.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Every body about me ſeem'd happy—but every body ſeem'd in a hurry to be happy ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And you like this?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: One muſt like what the reſt of the World likes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Pernicious maxim!

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: But, my dear Sir George, you have not promis'd to go with me to the Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: 'Twould be a ſhocking indecorum to be ſeen together, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Oh, no; I aſk'd Mrs. Racket, and ſhe told me we might be ſeen together at the Maſquerade—without being laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Indeed, to tell you the truth, I could wiſh it was the faſhion for married people to be inſeparable; for I have more heart-felt ſatisfaction in fifteen minutes with you at my ſide, than fifteen days of amuſement could give me without you.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: My ſweet Creature! How that confeſſion charms me!—Let us begin the Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p:
O, impoſſible! We ſhould not gain a ſingle proſelyte; and you can't conceive what ſpiteful things would be ſaid of us.—At Kenſington to-day a Lady met us, whom we ſaw at Court, when we were preſented; ſhe
lifted up her hands in amazement!—Bleſs me! ſaid ſhe to her companion, here's Lady Francis without Sir Hurlo Thrumbo!—My dear Mrs. Racket, conſider what an important charge you have! for Heaven's ſake take her home again, or ſome Enchanter on a flying Dragon will deſcend and carry her off. — Oh, ſaid another, I dare ſay Lady Frances has a clue at her heel, like the peerleſs Roſamond:—her tender ſwain would never have truſted her ſo far without ſuch a precaution.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Heav'n and Earth!—How ſhall Innocence preſerve its luſtre amidſt manners ſo corrupt! — My dear Fanny, I feel a ſentiment for thee at this moment, tenderer than Love — more animated than Paſſion.——I could weep over that purity, expos'd to the ſullying breath of Faſhion, and the Ton, in whoſe latitudinary vortex Chaſtity herſelf can ſcarcely move unſpotted.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Your Honour talk'd, I thought, ſomething about going to the Maſquerade?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: Isn't it?—hasn't your Honour?—I thought your Honour had forgot to order a Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Well conſider'd, Gibſon.—Come, will you be Jew, Turk, or Heretic; a Chineſe Emperor, or a Ballad-Singer; a Rake, or a Watchman?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Oh, neither, my Love; I can't take the trouble to ſupport a character.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: You'll wear a Domino then:—I ſaw a pink Domino trimm'd with blue at the ſhop where I bought my Habit.—Would you like it?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Any thing, any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Then go about it directly, Gibſon.—A pink Domino trimm'd with blue, and a Hat of the ſame— Come, you have not ſeen my Dreſs yet—it is moſt beautiful; I long to have it on.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir George and Lady Frances.

sp.speaker: Gib.
sp.p: A pink Domino trimm'd with blue, and a Hat of the ſame—What the devil can it ſignify to Sally now what his Dreſs is to be?—Surely the Slut has not made an aſſignation to meet her Maſter!

div.head: SCENE—A Maſquerade.
div.stage: A Party dancing Cotillons in front—a variety of Characters paſs and repaſs.
Enter Folly on a Hobby-Horſe, with Cap and Bells.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: HEY! Tom Fool! what buſineſs have you here?

sp.speaker: Foll.
sp.p: What, Sir! Affront a Prince in his own Dominions!Struts off.

sp.speaker: Mountebank.
sp.p: Who'll buy my Noſtrums? Who'll buy my Noſtrums?

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: What are they?They all come round him.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Different ſorts, and for different cuſtomers. Here's a Liquor for Ladies—it expels the rage of Gaming and Gallantry. Here's a Pill for Members of Parliament —good to ſettle Conſciences. Here's an Eye-Water for Jealous Huſbands—it thickens the Viſual Membrane, through which they ſee too clearly. Here's a Decoction for the Clergy—it never ſits eaſy, if the patient has more than One Living. Here's a Draught for Lawyers—a great promoter of Modeſty. Here's a Powder for Projectors—'twill rectify the fumes of an Empty Stomach, and diſſipate their airy caſtles.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: Have you a Noſtrum that can give patience to Young Heirs, whoſe Uncles and Fathers are ſtout and healthy?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yes; and I have an Infuſion for Creditors— it gives reſignation and humility, when Fine Gentlemen break their promiſes, or plead their privilege.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: Come along:—I'll find you cuſtomers for your whole cargo.

div.stage: Enter Hardy, in the Dreſs of Iſaac Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Hardy.
sp.p: Why, isn't it a ſhame to ſee ſo many ſtout, well-built Young Fellows, maſquerading, and cutting Couranta's here at home—inſtead of making the French cut capers to the tune of your Cannon—or ſweating the Spaniards with an Engliſh Fandango?—I foreſee the end of all this.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: Why, thou little teſty Iſraelite! back to Duke's Place; and preach your tribe into a ſubſcription for the good of the land on whoſe milk and honey ye fatten. — Where are your Joſhuas and your Gideons, aye? What! all dwindled into Stockbrokers, Pedlars, and Rag-Men?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, not all. Some of us turn Chriſtians, and by degrees grow into all the privileges of Engliſhmen! In the ſecond generation we are Patriots, Rebels, Courtiers, and Huſbands. Puts his fingers to his forehead.

sp.speaker: 3d Maſk.
sp.p: What, my little Iſaac!—How the Devil came you here? Where's your old Margaret?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Oh, I have got rid of her.

sp.speaker: 3d Maſk.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Why, I perſuaded a young Iriſhman that ſhe was a blooming plump Beauty of eighteen; ſo they made an Elopement, ha! ha! ha! and ſhe is now the Toaſt of Tipperary. Ha! there's Couſin Racket and her Party; they ſha'n't know me. Puts on his Maſk.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Racket, Lady Frances, Sir George, and Flutter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Look at this dumpling Jew; he muſt be a Levite by his figure. You have ſurely practiſed the fleſh-hook a long time, friend, to have raiſed that goodly preſence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: About as long, my briſk Widow, as you have been angling for a ſecond Huſband; but my hook has been better baited than your's.—You have only caught Gudgeons, I ſee. Pointing to Flutter.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Oh! this is one of the Geniuses they hire to entertain the Company with their accidental ſallies.—Let me look at your Common-Place Book, friend.—I want a few good things.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I'd oblige you, with all my heart; but you'll ſpoil them in repeating—or, if you ſhou'd not, they'll gain you no reputation—for no body will believe they are your own.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: He knows ye, Flutter;—the little Gentleman fancies himſelf a Wit, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: There's no depending on what you ſee—the eyes of the jealous are not to be truſted.—Look to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: He knows ye, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What! am I the Town-talk?Aſide

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I can neither ſee Doricourt nor Letty.—I muſt find them out. Exit Hardy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Well, Lady Frances, is not all this charming? Could you have conceived ſuch a brilliant aſſemblage of objects?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Delightful! The days of enchantment are reſtor'd; the columns glow with Sapphires and Rubies. Emperors and Fairies, Beauties and Dwarfs, meet me at every ſtep.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How lively are firſt impreſſions on ſenſible minds! In four hours, vapidity and languor will take place of that exquiſite ſenſe of joy, which flutters your little heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: What an inhuman creature! Fate has not allow'd us theſe ſenſations above ten times in our lives; and would you have us ſhorten them by anticipation?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: O Lord! your Wiſe Men are the greateſt Fools upon earth:—they reaſon about their enjoyments, and analyſe their pleaſures, whilſt the eſſence eſcapes. Look, Lady Frances: D'ye ſee that Figure ſtrutting in the dreſs of an Emperor? His Father retails Oranges in Botolph Lane. That Gypſey is a Maid of Honour, and that Rag-man a Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Why, you know every body.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Oh, every creature.—A Maſk is nothing at all to me.—I can give you the hiſtory of half the people here. In the next apartment there's a whole family, who, to my knowledge, have lived on Water-Creſſes this month, to make a figure here to-night;—but, to make up for that, they'll cram their pockets with cold Ducks and Chickens, for a Carnival to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhould like to ſee this provident Family.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Honour me with your arm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Come, Sir George, you ſhall be my Beau. —We'll make the tour of the rooms, and meet them. Oh! your pardon, you muſt follow Lady Frances; or the wit and fine parts of Mr. Flutter may drive you out of her head. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I was going to follow her, and now I dare not. How can I be ſuch a fool as to be govern'd by the fear of that ridicule which I deſpiſe! Exit Sir George.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Ha! my Lord!—I thought you had been engaged at Weſtminſter on this important night.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p:
So I am—I ſlipt out as ſoon as Lord Trope got upon his legs; I can badinage here an hour or two, and be back again before he is down.—There's a fine Figure! I'll addreſs her.
Enter Letitia. Charity, fair Lady! Charity for a poor Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Letit.
sp.p: Charity! If you mean my prayers, Heaven grant thee Wit, Pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: That bleſſing would do from a Devotee: from you I aſk other charities;—ſuch charities as Beauty ſhould beſtow—ſoft Looks—ſweet Words—and kind Wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Letit.
sp.p: Alas! I am bankrupt of theſe, and forced to turn Beggar myſelf.—There he is!—how ſhall I catch his attention?

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: Will you grant me no favour?

sp.speaker: Letit.
sp.p: Yes, one—I'll make you my Partner—not for life, but through the ſoft mazes of a minuet.—Dare you dance?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Some ſpirit in that.

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: I dare do any thing you command.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Do you know her, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Maſk.
sp.p: No: Such a woman as that, would formerly have been known in any diſguiſe; but Beauty is now common—Venus ſeems to have given her Ceſtus to the whole ſex.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: during the Minuet She dances divinely.— When ended Somebody muſt know her! Let us enquire who ſhe is. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Saville and Kitty Willis, habited like Lady Frances.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I have ſeen Courtall in Sir George's habit, though he endeavoured to keep himſelf conceal'd. Go, and ſeat yourſelf in the tea-room, and on no account diſcover your face:—remember too, Kitty, that the Woman you are to perſonate is a Woman of Virtue.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I am afraid I ſhall find that a difficult character: indeed I believe it is ſeldom kept up through a whole Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Of that you can be no judge—Follow my directions, and you ſhall be rewarded. Exit Kitty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ha! Saville! Did you ſee a Lady dance juſt now?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Very odd. No body knows her.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Where is Miſs Hardy?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Cutting Watch-papers, and making Conundrums, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Faith, I hardly know. She's not here, however, Mrs. Racket tells me.—I aſk'd no further.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Your indifference ſeems increas'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Quite the reverſe; 'tis advanced thirty-two degrees towards hatred.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You are jeſting?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then it muſt be with a very ill grace, my dear Saville; for I never felt ſo ſeriouſly: Do you know the creature's almoſt an Ideot?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: An Ideot. What the devil ſhall I do with her? Egad! I think I'll feign myſelf mad—and then Hardy will propoſe to cancel the engagements.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: An excellent expedient. I muſt leave you; you are myſterious, and I can't ſtay to unravel ye. — I came here to watch over Innocence and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Guardian of Innocence and Beauty at three and twenty! Is there not a cloven foot under that black gown, Saville?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p:
No, faith. Courtall is here on a moſt deteſtable deſign.—I found means to get a knowledge of the Lady's dreſs, and have brought a girl to perſonate her, whoſe
reputation cannot be hurt.—You ſhall know the reſult to-morrow. Adieu. Exit Saville.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: muſing Yes, I think that will do.—I'll feign myſelf mad, ſee the Doctor to pronounce me incurable, and when the parchments are deſtroyed—

div.stage: As he ſtands in a muſing poſture, Letitia enters, and ſings.

lg.l: Wake! thou Son of Dullneſs, wake!
All the ſpells that Care employs,

lg.head: II.
lg.l: All the gifts that Pleaſure ſends,

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Touch his feelings, rouze his ſoul,
Bid them wake to new delight,
Crown the magic of the night.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: By Heaven, the ſame ſweet creature!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You have choſen an odd ſituation for ſtudy. Faſhion and Taſte preſide in this ſpot:—they throw their ſpells around you: — ten thouſand delights ſpring up at their command;—and you, a Stoic—a being without ſenſes, are wrapt in reflection.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And you, the moſt charming being in the world, awake me to admiration. Did you come from the Stars?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yes, and I ſhall reaſcend in a moment.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray ſhew me your face before you go.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Beware of imprudent curioſity; it loſt Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Eve's curioſity was rais'd by the Devil;—'tis an Angel tempts mine.—So your alluſion is not in point.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But why would you ſee my face?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To fall in love with it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why, then—Aye, curſe it! there's the rub. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs will be angry;—but, perhaps, you have no Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, yes; and a ſweet one it is!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What! is ſhe old?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Ugly?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pho! don't talk about her; but ſhew me your face.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My vanity forbids it;—'twould frighten you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Your Shape is graceful, your Air bewitching, your Boſom tranſparent, and your Chin would tempt me to kiſs it, if I did not ſee a pouting red Lip above it, that demands—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You grow too free.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Shew me your face then—only half a glance.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Not for worlds.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What! you will have a little gentle force?Attempts to ſeize her Maſk.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I am gone for ever!Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe;—I'll follow to the end. Exit.

div.stage: Flutter, Lady Frances, and Saville advance.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: How can you be thus intereſted for a ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Goodneſs will ever intereſt; its home is Heaven: on earth 'tis but a Wanderer. Imprudent Lady! why have you left the ſide of your Protector? Where is your Huſband?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Why, what's that to him?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Surely it can't be merely his habit;— there's ſomething in him that awes me.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Pho! 'tis only his grey beard.—I know him; he keeps a Lottery-office on Cornhill.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: My province, as an Enchanter, lays open every ſecret to me. Lady! there are dangers abroad—Beware!

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis very odd; his manner has made me tremble. Let us ſeek Sir George.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: He is coming towards us.

div.stage: Courtall comes forward, habited like Sir George.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: There ſhe is! If I can but diſengage her from that fool Flutter—crown me, ye Schemers, with immortal wreaths.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: O my dear Sir George! I rejoice to meet you—an old Conjuror has been frightening me with his Prophecies.—Where's Mrs. Rackett?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: In the dancing-room.—I promis'd to ſend you to her, Mr. Flutter.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Ah! ſhe wants me to dance. With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Why do you keep on your maſk?—'tis too warm.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Tis very warm—I want air—let us go.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: You ſeem quite agitated.—Sha'n't we bid our company adieu?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No, no;—there's no time for forms. I'll juſt give directions to the carriage, and be with you in a moment. Going, ſteps back. Put on your maſk; I have a particular reaſon for it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Now, Kitty, you know your leſſon. Lady Frances, takes off his maſk let me lead you to your Huſband.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Heavens! is Mr. Saville the Conjuror? Sir George is juſt ſtept to the door to give directions.—We are going home immediately.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No, Madam, you are deceiv'd: Sir George is this way.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: This is aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Be not alarm'd: you have eſcap'd a ſnare, and ſhall be in ſafety in a moment.

div.stage: Enter Courtall, and ſeizes Kitty's Hand.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to go ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Perhaps I may bring you back, my Angel— but go now, you muſt. Exit. Muſic.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: By Heavens! I never was charm'd till now.— Engliſh beauty—French vivacity—wit—elegance. Your name, my Angel!—tell me your name, though you perſiſt in concealing your face.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My name has a ſpell in it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I thought ſo; it muſt be Charming.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: But if reveal'd, the charm is broke.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for its force.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Suppoſe it Harriet, or Charlotte, or Maria, or—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hang Harriet, and Charlotte, and Maria—the name your Father gave ye!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: That can't be worth knowing, 'tis ſo tranſient a thing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How, tranſient?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid my name ſhould be laſting till I am married.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Married! The chains of Matrimony are too heavy and vulgar for ſuch a ſpirit as yours.—The flowery wreaths of Cupid are the only bands you ſhould wear.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: They are the lighteſt, I believe: but 'tis poſſible to wear thoſe of Marriage gracefully.—Throw 'em looſely round, and twiſt 'em in a True-Lover's Knot for the Boſom.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: An Angel! But what will you be when a Wife?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
A Woman.—If my Huſband ſhould prove a Churl,
a Fool, or a Tyrant, I'd break his heart, ruin his fortune, elope with the firſt pretty Fellow that aſk'd me— and return the contempt of the world with ſcorn, whilſt my feelings prey'd upon my life.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Amazing! Aſide What if you lov'd him, and he were worthy of your love?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why, then I'd be any thing—and all!—Grave, gay, capricious — the ſoul of whim, the ſpirit of variety—live with him in the eye of faſhion, or in the ſhade of retirement—change my country, my ſex,— feaſt with him in an Eſquimaux hut, or a Perſian pavilion—join him in the victorious war-dance on the borders of Lake Ontario, or ſleep to the ſoft breathings of the flute in the cinnamon groves of Ceylon—dig with him in the mines of Golconda, or enter the dangerous precincts of the Mogul's Seraglo—cheat him of his wiſhes, and overturn his empire to reſtore the Huſband of my Heart to the bleſſings of Liberty and Love.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Delightful wildneſs! Oh, to catch thee, and hold thee for ever in this little cage!Attempting to claſp her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Hold, Sir! Though Cupid muſt give the bait that tempts me to the ſnare, 'tis Hymen muſt ſpread the net to catch me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to aſſume airs of coldneſs—Fate has ordain'd you mine.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I feel it here. I never met with a Woman ſo perfectly to my taſte; and I won't believe it form'd you ſo, on purpoſe to tantalize me.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: This moment is worth my whole exiſtence. Aſide

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come, ſhew me your face, and rivet my chains.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: To-morrow you ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To-morrow! and not to-night?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Where then ſhall I wait on you to-morrow?— Where ſee you?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee me in an hour when you leaſt expect me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why all this myſtery?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I like to be myſterious. At preſent be content to know that I am a Woman of Family and Fortune. Adieu!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Adieu! Then I am come at the fag end. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Let me ſee you to your carriage.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: As you value knowing me, ſtir not a ſtep. If I am follow'd, you never ſee me more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Barbarous Creature! She's gone! What, and is this really ſerious?—am I in love?—Pho! it can't be—O Flutter! do you know that charming Creature?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: What charming Creature? I paſs'd a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: She went out at that door, as you enter'd.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Oh, yes;—I know her very well.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do you, my dear Fellow? Who?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: She's kept by Lord George Jennett.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Impudent Scoundrel!Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Kept!!!

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Yes; Colonel Gorget had her firſt; — then Mr. Loveill;—then—I forget exactly how many; and at laſt ſhe's Lord George's. Talks to other Maſks.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll murder Gorget, poiſon Lord George, and ſhoot myſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now's the time, I ſee, to clear up the whole. Mr. Doricourt!—I ſay—Flutter was miſtaken; I know who you are in love with.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A ſtrange rencontre! Who?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My Letty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh! I underſtand your rebuke;—'tis too ſoon, Sir, to aſſume the Father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Zounds! what do you mean by that? I tell you that the Lady you admire, is Letitia Hardy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am glad you are ſo well ſatisfied with the ſtate of my heart.—I wiſh I was. Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Stop a moment.—Stop, I ſay! What, you won't? Very well—if I don't play you a trick for this, may I never be a Grand-father! I'll plot with Letty now, and not againſt her; aye, hang me if I don't. There's ſomething in my head, that ſhall tingle in his heart.— He ſhall have a lecture upon impatience, that I foreſee he'll be the better for as long as he lives. Exit.

div.stage: Saville comes forward with other Maſks.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Flutter, come with us; we're going to raiſe a laugh at Courtall's.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: With all my heart. "Live to Live," was my Father's motto: "Live to Laugh," is mine. Exit.

div.head: SCENE—Courtall's.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Where have you brought me, Sir George? This is not our home.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Tis my home, beautiful Lady Frances! Kneels, and takes off his Maſk. Oh, forgive the ardency of my paſſion, which has compell'd me to deceive you.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Mr. Courtall! what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, ſay but that you pardon the Wretch who adores you. Did you but know the agonizing tortures of my heart, ſince I had the felicity of converſing with you this morning—or the deſpair that now— Knock.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Oh! I'm undone!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Zounds! my dear Lady Frances. I am not at home. Raſcal! do you hear?—Let no body in; I am not at home.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Without Sir, I told the Gentlemen ſo.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Eternal curſes! they are coming up. Step into this room, adorable Creature! one moment; I'll throw them out of the window if they ſtay three.

div.stage: Exit Kitty, through the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: O Gemini! beg the Petticoat's pardon.—Juſt ſaw a corner of it.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Maſk.
sp.p: No wonder admittance was ſo difficult. I thought you took us for Bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, I am deviliſh glad to ſee you— but you perceive how I am circumſtanc'd. Excuſe me at this moment.

sp.speaker: 2d Maſk.
sp.p: Tell us who 'tis then.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, fie!

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: We won't blab.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I can't, upon honour.—Thus far—She's a Woman of the firſt Character and Rank. Saville, takes him aſide have I influence, or have I not?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Why, ſure, you do not inſinuate—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No, not inſinuate, but ſwear, that ſhe's now in my bed-chamber:—by gad, I don't deceive you.—There's Generalſhip, you Rogue! Such an humble, diſtant, ſighing Fellow as thou art, at the end of a ſix-months ſiege, would have boaſted of a kiſs from her glove.—I only give the ſignal, and—pop!—ſhe's in my arms.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What, Lady Fran—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Huſh! You ſhall ſee her name to-morrow morning in red letters at the end of my liſt. Gentlemen, you muſt excuſe me now. Come and drink chocolate at twelve, but—

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Aye, let us go, out of reſpect to the Lady:—'tis a Perſon of Rank.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Is it?—Then I'll have a peep at her. Runs to the door in the back Scene.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: This is too much, Sir. Trying to prevent him.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Maſk.
sp.p: By Jupiter, we'll all have a peep.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Gentlemen, conſider—for Heaven's ſake—a Lady of Quality. What will be the conſequences?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p:
The conſequences!—Why, you'll have your throat cut, that's all—but I'll write your Elegy. So,
now for the door! Part open the door, whilſt the reſt hold Courtall.—Beg your Ladyſhip's pardon, whoever you are: Leads her out. Emerge from darkneſs like the glorious Sun, and bleſs the wond'ring circle with your charms. Takes off her Maſk.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Kitty Willis! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Kitty Willis! ha! ha! ha! Kitty Willis!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Maſk.
sp.p: Why, what a Fellow you are, Courtall, to attempt impoſing on your friends in this manner! A Lady of Quality—an Earl's Daughter—Your Ladyſhip's moſt obedient.—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Courtall, have you influence, or have you not?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: The Man's moon-ſtruck.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hell, and ten thouſand Furies, ſeize you all together!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: What! me, too, Mr. Courtall? me, whom you have knelt to, pray'd to, and adored?

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: That's right, Kitty; give him a little more.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Diſappointed and laugh'd at!—

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Laugh'd at and deſpis'd. I have fullfiled my deſign, which was to expoſe your villainy, and laugh at your preſumption. Adieu, Sir! Remember how you again boaſt of your influence with Women of Rank; and, when you next want amuſement, dare not to look up to the virtuous and to the noble for a Companion.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: And, Courtall, before you carry a Lady into your bed-chamber again, look under her maſk, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: There's no bearing this! I'll ſet off for Paris directly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Villers.
sp.p: WHIMSICAL enough! I Dying for her, and hates her; believes her a Fool, and a Woman of brilliant Underſtanding!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: As true as you are alive;—but when I went up to him laſt night, at the Pantheon, out of downright good-nature to explain things—my Gentleman whips round upon his heel, and ſnapt me as ſhort as if I had been a beggar-woman with ſix children, and he Overſeer of the Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Here comes the Wonder-worker— Enter Letitia. Here comes the Enchantreſs, who can go to Maſquerades, and ſing and dance, and talk a Man out of his wits!— But pray, have we Morning Maſquerades?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Oh, no—but I am ſo enamour'd of this all-conquering Habit, that I could not reſiſt putting it on, the moment I had breakfaſted. I ſhall wear it on the day I am married, and then lay it by in ſpices—like the miraculous Robes of St. Bridget.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: That's as moſt Brides do. The charms that helped to catch the Huſband, are generally laid by, one after another, 'till the Lady grows a downright Wife, and then runs crying to her Mother, becauſe ſhe has transform'd her Lover into a downright Huſband.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Liſten to me.—I ha'n't ſlept to-night, for thinking of plots to plague Doricourt;—and they drove one another out of my head ſo quick, that I was as giddy as a gooſe, and could make nothing of 'em —I wiſh to goodneſs you could contrive ſomething.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Contrive to plague him! Nothing ſo eaſy. Don't undeceive him, Madam, 'till he is your Huſband. Marry him whilſt he poſſeſſes the ſentiments you labour'd to give him of Miſs Hardy—and when you are his Wife—

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! I ſee the whole—that's the very thing. My dear Mr. Villers, you are the divineſt Man.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Don't make love to me, Huſſey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: No, pray don't—for I deſign to have Villers myſelf in about ſix years.—There's an oddity in him that pleaſes me.—He holds Women in contempt; and I ſhould like to have an opportunity of breaking his heart for that.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: And when I am heartily tired of life, I know no Woman whom I would with more pleaſure make my Executioner.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It cannot be—I foreſee it will be impoſſible to bring it about. You know the wedding wasn't to take place this week or more—and Letty will never be able to play the Fool ſo long.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: The knot ſhall be tied to-night.—I have it all here, pointing to his forehead: the licence is ready. Feign yourſelf ill, ſend for Doricourt, and tell him you can't go out of the world in peace, except you ſee the ceremony performed.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I feign myſelf ill! I could as ſoon feign myſelf a Roman Ambaſſador.—I was never ill in my life, but with the tooth-ach—when Letty's Mother was a breeding I had all the qualms.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Oh, I have no fears for you.—But what ſays Miſs Hardy? Are you willing to make the irrevocable vow before night?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens!—I—I—'Tis ſo exceeding ſudden, that really—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p:
That really ſhe is frighten'd out of her wits—leſt it ſhould be impoſſible to bring matters about. But I have taken the ſcheme into my protection, and you
ſhall be Mrs. Doricourt before night. Come, to Mr. Hardy to bed directly: your room ſhall be cramm'd with phials, and all the apparatus of Death;—then heigh preſto! for Doricourt.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: You go and put off your conquering dreſs, to Letty and get all your aukward airs ready—And you practiſe a few groans to Hardy.—And you—if poſſible—an air of gravity to Mrs. Racket. I'll anſwer for the plot.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Married in jeſt! 'Tis an odd idea! Well, I'll venture it. Ex. Letitia and Mrs. Racket.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Aye, I'll be ſworn! looks at his watch 'tis paſt three. The Budget's to be open'd this morning. I'll juſt ſtep down to the Houſe.—Will you go?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What! with a mortal ſickneſs?

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: What a Blockhead! I believe, if half of us were to ſtay away with mortal ſickneſſes, it would be for the health of the Nation. Good-morning.—Ill call and feel your pulſe as I come back. Exit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You won't find 'em over briſk, I fancy. I foreſee ſome ill happening from this making believe to die before one's time. But hang it—a-hem!—I am a ſtout man yet; only fifty-ſix—What's that? In the laſt Yearly Bill there were three lived to above an hundred. Fifty-ſix!— Fiddle-de-dee! I am not afraid, not I. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Undreſs'd ſo late?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: I didn't go to bed 'till late—'twas late before I ſlept-late when I roſe. Do you know Lord George Jennett?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Has he a Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: What ſort of a creature is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Why, ſhe ſpends him three thouſand a year with the eaſe of a Ducheſs, and entertains his friends with the grace of a Ninon. Ergo, ſhe is handſome, ſpirited, and clever. Doricourt walks about diſordered. In the name of Caprice, what ails you?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: You have hit it—Elle eſt mon Caprice—The Miſtreſs of Lord George Jennett is my caprice—Oh, inſufferable!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What, you ſaw her at the Maſquerade?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Saw her, lov'd her, died for her—without knowing her—And now the curſe is, I can't hate her.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Ridiculous enough! All this diſtreſs about a Kept Woman, whom any man may have, I dare ſwear, in a fortnight—They've been jarring ſome time.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Have her! The ſentiment I have conceived for the Witch is ſo unaccountable, that, in that line, I cannot bear her idea. Was ſhe a Woman of Honour, for a Wife, I cou'd adore her—but, I really believe, if ſhe ſhould ſend me an aſſignation, I ſhould hate her.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Hey-day! This ſounds like Love. What becomes of poor Miſs Hardy?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Her name has given me an ague. Dear Saville, how ſhall I contrive to make old Hardy cancel the engagements! The moiety of the eſtate which he will forfeit, ſhall be his the next moment, by deed of gift.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Let me ſee—Can't you get it inſinuated that you are a dev'liſh wild fellow; that you are an Infidel, and attached to wenching, gaming, and ſo forth?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Aye, ſuch a character might have done ſome good two centuries back.—But who the devil can it frighten now? I believe it muſt be the mad ſcheme, at laſt.—There, will that do for the grin?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Ridiculous!—But, how are you certain that the Woman who has ſo bewildered you, belongs to Lord George?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Flutter told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Then fifty to one againſt the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo. There was a myſtery in her manner, for which nothing elſe can account. A violent rap. Who can this be?Saville looks out.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: The proverb is your anſwer—'tis Flutter himſelf. Tip him a ſcene of the Mad-man, and ſee how it takes.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: I will—a good way to ſend it about town. Shall it be of the melancholy kind, or the raving?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Rant!—rant!—Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Talk not to me who can pull comets by the beard, and overſet an iſland!
There! This is he!—this is he who hath ſent my poor ſoul, without coat or breeches, to be toſſed about in ether like a duck-feather! Villain, give me my ſoul again!

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul I hav'n't got it. Exceedingly frightened.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Flutter, what a melancholy ſight!—I little thought to have ſeen my poor friend reduced to this.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Mercy defend me! What's he mad?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You ſee how it is. A curſed Italian Lady—Jealouſy—gave him a drug; and every full of the moon—

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Moon! Who dares talk of the Moon? The patroneſs of genius—the rectifier of wits—the—Oh! here ſhe is!—I feel her—ſhe tugs at my brain—ſhe has it—ſhe has it—Oh!Exit.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Well! this is dreadful! exceeding dreadful, I proteſt. Have you had Monro?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Not yet. The worthy Miſs Hardy—what a misfortune!

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Aye, very true.—Do they know it?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Oh, no; the paroxyſm ſeized him but this morning.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Adieu! I can't ſtay. Going in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: But you muſt. holding him Stay, and aſſiſt me: —perhaps he'll return again in a moment; and, when he is in this way, his ſtrength is prodigious.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Can't indeed—can't upon my ſoul. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Flutter—Don't make a miſtake, now;—remember 'tis Doricourt that's mad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Yes—you mad.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No, no; Doricourt.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Egad, I'll ſay you are both mad, and then I can't miſtake. Exeunt ſeverally.

div.head: SCENE III.—.Sir George Touchwood's.
div.stage: Enter Sir George, and Lady Frances.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: The bird is eſcaped—Courtall is gone to France.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Heaven and earth! Have ye been to ſeek him?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Seek him! Aye.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: How did you get his name? I ſhould never have told it you.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I learnt it in the firſt Coffee-houſe I entered.— Every body is full of the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Thank Heaven! he's gone!—But I have a ſtory for you—The Hardy family are forming a plot upon your Friend Doricourt, and we are expected in the evening to aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Angel; but I can't ſtay to hear it unfolded. They told me Mr. Saville would be at home in half an hour, and I am impatient to ſee him. The adventure of laſt night—

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Think of it only with gratitude. The danger I was in has overſet a new ſyſtem of conduct, that, perhaps, I was too much inclined to adopt. But henceforward, my dear Sir George, you ſhall be my conſtant Companion, and Protector. And, when they ridicule the unfaſhionable Monſters, the felicity of our hearts ſhall make their ſatire pointleſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Charming Angel! You almoſt reconcile me to Courtall. Hark! here's company ſtepping to the door. 'Tis your lively Widow—I'll ſtep down the back ſtairs, to eſcape her. Exit Sir George.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Oh, Lady Frances! I am ſhock'd to death. —Have you received a card from us?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Yes; within theſe twenty minutes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Aye, 'tis of no conſequence.—'Tis all over—Doricourt is mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Mad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: My poor Letitia!—Juſt as we were enjoying ourſelves with the proſpect of a ſcheme that was planned for their mutual happineſs, in came Flutter, breathleſs, with the intelligence:—I flew here to know if you had heard it.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: No, indeed—and I hope it is one of Mr. Flutter's dreams.
A-propos; now we ſhall be informed. Mr. Saville, I rejoice to ſee you, though Sir George will be diſappointed: he's gone to your lodgings.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I ſhould have been happy to have prevented Sir George. I hope your Ladyſhip's adventure laſt night did not diſturb your dreams?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Not at all; for I never ſlept a moment. My eſcape, and the importance of my obligations to you, employed my thoughts. But we have juſt had ſhocking intelligence—Is is true that Doricourt is mad?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: So; the buſineſs is done. Aſide. Madam, I am ſorry to ſay, that I have juſt been a melancholy witneſs of his ravings: he was in the height of a paroxyſm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Oh, there can be no doubt of it. Flutter told us the whole hiſtory. Some Italian Princeſs gave him a drug, in a box of ſweetmeats, ſent to him by her own page; and it renders him lunatic every month. Poor Miſs Hardy! I never felt ſo much on any occaſion in my life.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: To ſoften your concern, I will inform you, Madam, that Miſs Hardy is leſs to be pitied than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: 'Tis rather a delicate ſubject—but he did not love Miſs Hardy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: He did love Miſs Hardy, Sir, and would have been the happieſt of men.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam; his heart was not only free from that Lady's chains, but abſolutely captivated by another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: No, Sir—no. It was Miſs Hardy who captivated him. She met him laſt night at the Maſquerade, and charmed him in diſguiſe—He profeſſed the moſt violent paſſion for her; and a plan was laid, this evening, to cheat him into happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Upon my ſoul, I muſt beg your pardon; I have not eaten of the Italian Princeſs's box of ſweetmeats, ſent by her own page; and yet I am as mad as Doricourt, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: So it appears—What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Why, Madam, he is at preſent in his perfect ſenſes; but he'll loſe 'em in ten minutes, through joy.— The madneſs was only a feint, to avoid marrying Miſs Hardy, ha! ha! ha!—I'll carry him the intelligence directly. Going.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Not for worlds. I owe him revenge, now, for what he has made us ſuffer. You muſt promiſe not to divulge a ſyllable I have told you; and when Doriricourt is ſummoned to Mr. Hardy's, prevail on him to come—madneſs, and all.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Pray do. I ſhould like to ſee him ſhewing off, now I am in the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You muſt be obeyed; though 'tis inhuman to conceal his happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: I am going home; ſo I'll ſet you down at his lodgings, and acquaint you, by the way, with our whole ſcheme. Allons!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I attend you leading her out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: You won't fail us?

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: No; depend on us. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: flings away the book What effect can the morals of Fourſcore have on a mind torn with paſſion? muſing Is it poſſible ſuch a ſoul as her's, can ſupport itſelf in ſo humiliating a ſituation? A kept Woman! riſing Well, well—I am glad it is ſo—I am glad it is ſo!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What a happy dog you are, Doricourt! I might have been mad, or beggar'd, or piſtol'd myſelf, without its being mentioned—But you, forſooth! the whole Female World is concerned for. I reported the ſtate of your brain to five different women—The lip of the firſt trembled; the white boſom of the ſecond heaved a ſigh; the third ejaculated, and turned her eye—to the glaſs; the fourth bleſſed herſelf; and the fifth ſaid, whilſt ſhe pinned a curl, Well, now, perhaps, he'll be an amuſing Companion; his native dullneſs was intolerable.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Envy! ſheer envy, by the ſmiles of Hebe!— There are not leſs than forty pair of the brighteſt eyes in town will drop cryſtals, when they hear of my misfortune.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Well, but I have news for you:—Poor Hardy is confined to his bed; they ſay he is going out of the world by the firſt poſt, and he wants to give you his bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Ill! ſo ill! I am ſorry from my ſoul. He's a worthy little Fellow—if he had not the gift of foreſeeing ſo ſtrongly.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Well; you muſt go and take leave.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: What! to act the Lunatic in the dying Man's chamber?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Exactly the thing; and will bring your buſineſs to a ſhort iſſue: for his laſt commands muſt be, That you are not to marry his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: That's true, by Jupiter!—and yet, hang it, impoſe upon a poor fellow at ſo ſerious a moment!— I can't do it.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You muſt, 'faith. I am anſwerable for your appearance, though it ſhould be in a ſtrait waiſtcoat. He knows your ſituation, and ſeems the more deſirous of an interview.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: I don't like encountering Racket.—She's an arch little devil, and will diſcover the cheat.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: There's a fellow!—Cheated Ninety-nine Women; and now afraid of the Hundredth.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: And with reaſon—for that hundredth is a Widow Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V. Hardy's.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Racket, and Miſs Ogle.

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: And ſo Miſs Hardy is actually to be married to-night?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: If her Fate does not deceive her. You are appriſed of the ſcheme, and we hope it will ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: Deuce take her! ſhe's ſix years younger than I am. Aſide—Is Mr. Doricourt handſome?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Handſome, generous, young, and rich.— There's a Huſband for ye! Isn't he worth pulling caps for?

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: I' my conſcience, the Widow ſpeaks as though ſhe'd give cap, ears, and all for him. Aſide. I wonder you didn't try to catch this wonderful Man, Mrs. Racket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p:
Really, Miſs Ogle, I had not time. Beſides, when I marry, ſo many ſtout young fellows will
hang themſelves, that, out of regard to ſociety, in theſe ſad times, I ſhall poſtpone it for a few years. This will coſt her a new lace—I heard it crack. Aſide.

div.stage: Enter Sir George, and Lady Frances.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Well, here we are.—But where's the Knight of the Woeful Countenance?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Here ſoon, I hope—for a woeful Night it will be without him.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Oh, fie! do you condeſcend to pun?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Why not? It requires genius to make a good pun—ſome men of bright parts can't reach it. I know a Lawyer who writes them on the back of his briefs; and ſays they are of great uſe—in a dry cauſe.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Here they come!—Here they come!—Their coach ſtopped, as mine drove off.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Then Miſs Hardy's fate is at a criſis.— She plays a hazardous game, and I tremble for her.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: without Come, let me guide you!—This way, my poor Friend! Why are you ſo furious?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p:
without The Houſe of Death—to the Houſe of Death!
Enter Doricourt, and Saville. Ah! this is the ſpot!

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: How wild and fiery he looks!

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: Now, I think, he looks terrified.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Poor creature, how his eyes work!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: I never ſaw a Madman before—Let me examine him—Will he bite?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Pray keep out of his reach, Ladies—You don't know your danger. He's like a Wild Cat, if a ſudden thought ſeiſes him.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: You talk like a Keeper of Wild Cats—How much do you demand for ſhewing the Monſter?

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p:
I don't like this—I muſt rouſe their ſenſibility. There! there ſhe darts through the air in liquid flames!
Down again! Now I have her—Oh, ſhe burns, ſhe ſcorches!—Oh! ſhe eats into my very heart!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: He ſees the Apparition of the wicked Italian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Keep her Highneſs faſt, Doricourt.

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: Give her a pinch, before you let her go.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: I am laughed at!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Laughed at—aye, to be ſure; why, I could play the Madman better than you▪—There! there ſhe is! Now I have her! Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: I knew that Devil would diſcover me. Aſide I'll leave the houſe:—I'm covered with confuſion. Going.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—You muſt not go. 'Twas poorly done, Mr. Doricourt, to affect madneſs, rather than fulfil your engagements.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Affect madneſs!—Saville, what can I do?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Since you are diſcovered, confeſs the whole.

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: Aye, turn Evidence, and ſave Yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Yes; ſince my deſigns have been ſo unaccountably diſcovered, I will avow the whole. I cannot love Miſs Hardy—and I will never —

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Hold, my dear Doricourt! be not ſo raſh. What will the world ſay to ſuch —

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Damn the world! What will the world give me for the loſs of happineſs? Muſt I ſacrifice my peace, to pleaſe the world?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Yes, every thing, rather than be branded with diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Though our arguments ſhould fail, there is a Pleader, whom you ſurely cannot withſtand—the dying Mr. Hardy ſupplicates you not to forſake his Child.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p:
Mr. Hardy requeſts you to grant him a moment's
converſation, Mr. Doricourt, though you ſhould perſiſt ſo ſend him miſerable to the grave. Let me conduct you to his chamber.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Oh, aye, any where; to the Antipodes—to the Moon—Carry me—Do with me what you will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack
sp.p: Mortification and diſappointment, then, are ſpecifics in a caſe of ſtubbornneſs.—I'll follow, and let you know what paſſes.

div.stage: Exeunt Villers, Doricourt, Mrs. Racket, and Miſs Ogle.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Ladies, Ladies, have the charity to take me with you, that I may make no blunder in repeating the ſtory. Exit Flutter.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Sir George, you don't know Mr. Saville.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ten thouſand pardons—but I will not pardon myſelf, for not obſerving you. I have been with the utmoſt impatience at your door twice to-day.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I am concerned you had ſo much trouble, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Trouble! what a word!—I hardly know how to addreſs you; I am diſtreſſed beyond meaſure; and it is the higheſt proof of my opinion of your honour, and the delicacy of your mind, that I open my heart to you.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What has diſturbed you, Sir George?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Your having preſerved Lady Frances, in ſo imminent a danger. Start not, Saville; to protect Lady Frances, was my right. You have wreſted from me my deareſt privilege.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I hardly know how to anſwer ſuch a reproach. I cannot apologize for what I have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I do not mean to reproach you; I hardly know what I mean. There is one method by which you may reſtore peace to me; I cannot endure that my Wife ſhould be ſo infinitely indebted to any man who is leſs than my Brother.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Pray explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I have a Siſter, Saville, who is amiable; and you are worthy of her, I ſhall give her a commiſſion to ſteal your heart, out of revenge for what you have done.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I am infinitely honoured, Sir George; but —

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I cannot liſten to a ſentence which begins with ſo unpromiſing a word. You muſt go with us into Hampſhire; and, if you ſee each other with the eyes I do, your felicity will be complete. I know no one, to whoſe heart I would ſo readily commit the care of my Siſter's happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I will attend you to Hampſhire, with pleaſure; but not on the plan of retirement. Society has claims on Lady Frances, that forbid it.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Claims, Saville!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Yes, claims; Lady Frances was born to be the ornament of Courts. She is ſufficiently alarmed, not to wander beyond the reach of her Protector;—and, from the Britiſh Court, the moſt tenderly-anxious Huſband could not wiſh to baniſh his Wife. Bid her keep in her eye the bright Example who preſides there; the ſplendour of whoſe rank yields to the ſuperior luſtre of her Virtue.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I allow the force of your argument. Now for intelligence!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Racket, Lady Frances, and Flutter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'ns! do you know —

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Let me tell the ſtory—As ſoon as Doricourt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: I proteſt you ſha'n't—ſaid Mr. Hardy—

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: No, 'twas Doricourt ſpoke firſt—ſays he—No, 'twas the Parſon—ſays he —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Stop his mouth, Sir George—he'll ſpoil the tale.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Never heed circumſtances—the reſult—the reſult.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p:
No, no; you ſhall have it in form.—Mr. Hardy performed the Sick Man like an Angel—He ſat
up in his bed, and talked ſo pathetically, that the tears ſtood in Doricourt's eyes.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Aye, ſtood—they did not drop, but ſtood.—I ſhall, in future, be very exact. The Parſon ſeized the moment; you know, they never miſs an opportunity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Make haſte, ſaid Doricourt; if I have time to reflect, poor Hardy will die unhappy.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: They were got as far as the Day of Judgement, when we ſlipt out of the room.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Then, by this time, they muſt have reached Amazement, which, every body knows, is the end of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Aye, the Reverend Fathers ended the ſervice with that word, Prophetically—to teach the Bride what a capricious Monſter a Huſband is.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I rather think it was Sarcaſtically—to prepare the Bridegroom for the unreaſonable humours and vagaries of his Help-mate.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: Here comes the Bridegroom of to-night.

div.stage: Enter Doricourt and Villers.—Villers whiſpers Saville, who goes out.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Joy! joy! joy!

sp.speaker: Miſs Ogle.
sp.p: If he's a ſample of Bridegrooms, keep me ſingle!—A younger Brother, from the Funeral of his Father, could not carry a more fretful countenance.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Oh!—Now, he's melancholy mad, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Fran.
sp.p: You do not conſider the importance of the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: No; nor how ſhocking a thing it is for a Man to be forced to marry one Woman, whilſt his heart is devoted to another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Well, now 'tis over, I confeſs to you, Mr. Doricourt, I think 'twas a moſt ridiculous piece of Quixotiſm, to give up the happineſs of a whole life to a Man who perhaps has but a few moments to be ſenſible of the ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: So it appeared to me.—But, thought I, Mr. Doricourt has travelled—he knows beſt.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Zounds! Confuſion!—Did ye not all ſet upon me?—Didn't ye talk to me of Honour—Compaſſion— Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Very true—You have acted according to their dictates, and I hope the utmoſt felicity of the Married State will reward you.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Never, Sir George! To Felicity I bid adieu— but I will endeavour to be content. Where is my—I muſt ſpeak it—where is my Wife?

div.stage: Enter Letitia, maſked, led by Saville.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Mr. Doricourt, this Lady was preſſing to be introduced to you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh!Starting.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I told you laſt night, you ſhou'd ſee me at a time when you leaſt expected me and I have kept my promiſe.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: Whoever you are, Madam, you could not have arrived at a happier moment.—Mr. Doricourt is juſt married.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Married! Impoſſible! 'Tis but a few hours ſince he ſwore to me eternal Love: I believ'd him, gave him up my Virgin heart—and now!—Ungrateful Sex!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Virgin heart! No, Lady—my fate, thank Heaven! yet wants that torture. Nothing but the conviction that you was another's, could have made me think one moment of Marriage, to have ſaved the lives of half Mankind. But this viſit, Madam, is as barbarous as unexpected. It is now my duty to forget you, which, ſpite of your ſituation, I found difficult enough.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My ſituation!—What ſituation?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I muſt apologiſe for explaining it in this company —but, Madam, I am not ignorant, that you are the companion of Lord George Jennet—and this is the only circumſtance that can give me peace.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
〈◊〉 mdash;a Companion! Ridiculous pretence! No, Sir,
know, to your confuſion, that my heart, my honour, my name is unſpotted as her's you have married; my birth equal to your own, my fortune large—That, and my perſon, might have been your's.—But, Sir, farewell!Going.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay a moment—Raſcal! is ſhe not —

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Who, ſhe? O Lard! no—'Twas quite a different perſon that I meant.—I never ſaw that Lady before.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then, never ſhalt thou ſee her more. Shakes Flutter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: Have mercy upon the poor Man!—Heavens! He'll murder him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Murder him! Yes, you, myſelf, and all Mankind. Sir George—Saville—Villers—'twas you who puſh'd me on this precipice;—'tis you who have ſnatch'd from me joy, felicity, and life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rack.
sp.p: There! Now, how well he acts the Madman!—This is ſomething like! I knew he would do it well enough, when the time came.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hard-hearted Woman! enjoy my ruin—riot in my wretchedneſs. Hardy burſts in.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: This is too much. You are now the Huſband of my Daughter; and how dare you ſhew all this paſſion about another Woman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alive again!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Alive! aye, and merry. Here, wipe off the flour from my face. I was never in better health and ſpirits in my life.—I foreſaw t'would do—.Why, my illneſs was only a fetch, Man! to make you marry Letty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
It was! Baſe and ungenerous! Well, Sir, you ſhall be gratified. The poſſeſſion of my heart was no object either with You, or your Daughter. My fortune and name was all you deſired, and theſe—I leave ye. My native England I ſhall quit, nor ever behold you more. But, Lady, that in my exile I may have one conſolation, grant me the favour you denied laſt night;—let me behold
all that maſk conceals, that your whole image may be impreſs'd on my heart, and chear my diſtant ſolitary hours.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: 'This is the moſt awful moment of my life. Oh, Doricourt, the ſlight action of taking off my Maſk, ſtamps me the moſt bleſt or miſerable of Women!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What can this mean? Reveal your face, I conjure you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Behold it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Rapture! Tranſport! Heaven!

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: Now for a touch of the happy Madman.

sp.speaker: Vill.
sp.p: This ſcheme was mine.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I will not allow that. This little ſtratagem aroſe from my diſappointment, in not having made the impreſſion on you I wiſh'd. The timidity of the Engliſh character threw a veil over me, you could not penetrate. You have forced me to emerge in ſome meaſure from my natural reſerve, and to throw off the veil that hid me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am yet in a ſtate of intoxication—I cannot anſwer you.—Speak on, ſweet Angel!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: You ſee I can be any thing; chuſe then my character—your Taſte ſhall fix it. Shall I be an Engliſh Wife?—or, breaking from the bonds of Nature and Education, ſtep forth to the world in all the captivating glare of Foreign Manners?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You ſhall be nothing but yourſelf—nothing can be captivating that you are not. I will not wrong your penetration, by pretending that you won my heart at the firſt interview; but you have now my whole ſoul—your perſon, your face, your mind, I would not exchange for thoſe of any other Woman breathing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
A Dog! how well he makes up for paſt ſlights! Couſin Racket, I wiſh you a good Huſband with all my heart. Mr. Flutter, I'll believe every word you ſay this fortnight. Mr. Villers, you and I have manag'd
this to a T. I never was ſo merry in my life—'Gad, I believe I can dance. Footing.

sp.speaker: Doric.
sp.p: Charming, charming creature!

sp.speaker: Letit.
sp.p: Congratulate me, my dear friends! Can you conceive my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, congratulate me; for mine is the greateſt.

sp.speaker: Flut.
sp.p: No, congratulate me, that I have eſcaped with life, and give me ſome ſticking plaſter—this wild cat has torn the ſkin from my throat.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: I expect to be among the firſt who are congratulated—for I have recovered one Angel, while Doricourt has gained another.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pho! pho! Don't talk of Angels, we ſhall be happier by half as Mortals. Come into the next room; I have order'd out every drop of my Forty-eight, and I'll invite the whole pariſh of St. George's, but what we'll drink it out—except one dozen, which I ſhall keep under three double locks, for a certain Chriſtening, that I foreſee will happen within this twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My charming Bride! It was a ſtrange perverſion of Taſte, that led me to conſider the delicate timidity of your deportment, as the mark of an uninform'd mind, or inelegant manners. I feel now it is to that innate modeſty, Engliſh Huſbands owe a felicity the Married Men of other nations are ſtrangers to: it is a ſacred veil to your own charms; it is the ſureſt bulwark to your Huſband's honour; and curſed be the hour—ſhould it ever arrive— in which Britiſh Ladies ſhall ſacrifice to foreign Graces the Grace of Modeſty!

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: NAY ceaſe, and hear me—I am come to ſcold—
Whence this night's plaudits, to a thought ſo old?
To gain a Lover, hid behind a Maſk!
What's new in that? or where's the mighty taſk?
For inſtance, now—What Lady Bab, or Grace,
E'er won a Lover—in her natural Face?
Miſtake me not—French red, or blanching creams,
I ſtoop not to—for thoſe are hackney'd themes;
The arts I mean, are harder to detect,
Eaſier put on, and worn to more effect;—
As thus —
Do Pride and Envy, with their horrid lines,
Deſtroy th' effect of Nature's ſweet deſigns?
The Maſk of Softneſs is at once applied,
And gentleſt manners ornament the Bride.
Do thoughts too free inform the Veſtal's eye,
Or point the glance, or warm the ſtruggling ſigh?
Not Dian's brows more rigid looks diſcloſe;
And Virtue's bluſh appears, where Paſſion glows.
And you, my gentle Sirs, wear Vizors too;
But here I'll ſtrip you, and expoſe to view
Your hidden features—Firſt I point at you.
That well-ſtuff'd waiſtcoat, and that rudily check;
That ample forehead, and that ſkin ſo ſleek,
Point out good-nature, and a gen'rous heart—
Tyrant! ſtand forth, and, conſcious, own thy part:
Thy Wife, thy Children, tremble in thy eye;
And Peace is baniſh'd —when the Father's nigh.
Sure 'tis enchantment! See, from ev'ry ſide
The Maſks fall off!—In charity I hide
The monſtrous features ruſhing to my view—
Fear not, there, Grand-Papa—nor you—nor you:
For ſhould I ſhew your features to each other,
Not one amongſt ye'd know his Friend, or Brother.
'Tis plain, then, all the world, from Youth to Age,
Appear in Maſks—Here, only, on the Stage,
You ſee us as we are: Here truſt your eyes;
Our wiſh to pleaſe, admits of no diſguiſe.

div.head: ERRATA:
div.p: Page 59. For my, read a whole exiſtence.

div.head: Of the Publiſher may be had, By the ſame AUTHOR,
div.p: THE MAID OF ARRAGON, a Poem, Part I.
*⁎* The whole of Mrs. COWLEY'S Dramatic Works, that have been publiſhed, may be had in One Volume, Price 5s. 9d. in boards, 6s. 6d. bound.
